statement.text: Chylous ascites is the accumulation of lymphatic chyle in the peritoneal cavity, resulting from disruption or obstruction of intra-abdominal lymphatics or the cisterna chyli, most commonly caused by malignancy, surgery (especially aortic or retroperitoneal procedures), or cirrhosis with lymphatic hypertension.

explanation.intuition: When lymphatic channels draining the intestines are damaged or blocked, the milky fat-rich fluid leaks into the belly instead of reaching the bloodstream. This causes abdominal distension and progressive nutritional problems from losing fats, proteins, and immune cells.
explanation.key_insight: Chylous ascites differs from chylothorax in etiology - malignancy (especially lymphoma) is the leading cause in adults, followed by surgery. The cisterna chyli and major intestinal lymphatics are vulnerable during aortic, pancreatic, and retroperitoneal surgery.
explanation.technical_details: Ascitic fluid analysis shows triglycerides >200 mg/dL (some use >110 mg/dL), milky appearance, cholesterol:TG ratio <1, and lymphocyte predominance. In children, chylous ascites is often congenital (lymphatic malformations); in adults, malignancy and surgery predominate. Aortic surgery risk is highest with retroperitoneal lymphadenectomy or extensive dissection near the cisterna chyli at L1-L2. Portal hypertension can cause secondary lymphatic overload. Management parallels chylothorax: dietary modification (MCT, NPO, TPN), octreotide, paracentesis/drainage, and surgical exploration or lymphangiography/embolization for refractory cases.

etiology.malignancy: Lymphoma (most common in adults), abdominal tumors, metastatic disease
etiology.cirrhosis: Hepatic lymphatic hypertension from portal hypertension

diagnosis.differential: Pseudochylous ascites (cholesterol-rich from chronic inflammation) has TG <200 and high cholesterol

complications.nutritional: Malnutrition, fat-soluble vitamin deficiency (A, D, E, K)

conservative.dietary: MCT diet or NPO with TPN

surgical.peritoneovenous_shunt: LeVeen or Denver shunt for refractory cases

definition.@value: Accumulation of triglyceride-rich lymphatic fluid in the peritoneal cavity due to lymphatic injury, obstruction, or lymphatic hypertension.

learning_objectives: Define chylous ascites and differentiate from pseudochylous
Identify surgical procedures at risk for chylous ascites
Understand the role of MCT diet in conservative management
clinical_pearls: Triglycerides >200 mg/dL in ascitic fluid is diagnostic
Pseudochylous ascites has LOW triglycerides, HIGH cholesterol - different entity
Aortic surgery near L1-L2 risks cisterna chyli injury
Lymphoma is the #1 cause in adults - always rule out malignancy
MCT diet works because MCTs go to portal vein, not lymphatics
Conservative management for 2-4 weeks before considering surgical intervention
